race.name: Race to Valhalla
race.tagline: South Carolina mountain gravel in Walhalla.

terrain.surface: Gravel roads through upstate SC mountains. Significant elevation with mountain scenery.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Regional SC event. Mountain terrain is nice but moderate organization and regional field.

biased_opinion.summary: Race to Valhalla is a regional event in Walhalla, South Carolina—upstate mountain terrain with significant elevation. The mountain scenery is nice, but the moderate organization and regional field keep it firmly in Tier 3. Walhalla provides moderate access.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid regional South Carolina gravel race with mountain terrain. Worth it for South Carolina cyclists seeking a mountain event. Not a destination race for out-of-state travelers.

final_verdict.one_liner: South Carolina mountain gravel in Walhalla.
final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're in South Carolina and want a mountain event—yes, it's solid. If you're from out of state—there are better options.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better SC events: Gran Fondo Hincapie. For similar mountain events: other SC gravel races.

logistics.food: Small town with limited dining. Stock nutrition.

course_description.character: SC mountain gravel with significant climbing.
course_description.ridewithgps_name: Official SEG The Race to Valhalla long course

non_negotiables.why: SC mountains require solid climbing fitness (5500 feet).

marketplace_variables.race_hook: South Carolina mountain gravel in Walhalla.

logistics.explanation: Registration stays open until 9 AM race morning, which edistoed calls "incredibly welcoming" but screams last-minute scramble. The course includes private Coppermine Road that you can't pre-ride, with organizers warning "DO NOT ride Coppermine road" until race day.

length.explanation: The long course spans 72 miles with 7,300 feet of climbing, won by Johnny Mitchell in 3:45:51. Winding Stairs Road alone "can take the better part of a half hour to climb," making every mile count more than flat centuries.

technicality.explanation: Course features "lots of long punishing climbs and tricky, fast, loose descents" with Forest Service road surfaces ranging from "some smooth crush, some chunky." The Chattooga River sections and steep winding gravel on Winding Stairs Road demand real bike handling skills.

elevation.explanation: 7,300 feet of climbing over 72 miles delivers mountain gravel suffering rare in the Southeast. The signature Winding Stairs Road climb from Lake Cherokee takes "the better part of a half hour" and comes early in the course, setting the tone for sustained mountain terrain.

climate.explanation: Late April timing hits "the best time to ride in the Carolinas" with "temps cool to start and won't be too hot yet." But spring weather in the mountains means anything from perfect conditions to cold rain with zero predictability.

altitude.explanation: Starting around 1,000 feet in Walhalla doesn't create altitude training effects or breathing issues. The elevation gain comes from climbing volume through Oconee County mountains, not thin air that affects your lungs.

adventure.explanation: Private roads like Coppermine that you can only access on race day, plus 30-minute climbs on Winding Stairs Road deliver the suffer-fest most gravel races promise. Long gravel roads "with no traffic" along the Chattooga River create exploration opportunities.

prestige.explanation: Part of the Southeast Gravel Series with 267 total finishers in 2025, but lacks the elite field depth of major events. One participant notes it's "a real test" with "scenery and no traffic," though it remains regional in scope.

race_quality.explanation: Edistoed calls last year's route "one of my favorites" and the finish has "a cool vibe that you usually only get in events like Unbound." Aid stations at miles 19.3 and 57.5 provide water, gels, and mechanical support, though organization feels casual.

experience.explanation: "Feel like a pro as you ride down Main Street all the way to the finish line while the town comes out to watch and cheer." The downtown finish with closed streets creates atmosphere beyond typical gravel parking lot endings, enhanced by festival timing.

community.explanation: The entire town of Walhalla comes out for the event, held during the Mother's Day Art Walk festival. Free hot meal and cold beer await finishers, with "festival type atmosphere" encouraging riders to stay and cheer others home.

field_depth.explanation: Johnny Mitchell won the long course in 3:45:51 among 116 finishers, while the short course drew 151 riders. The field spans age groups from teens to 70+, but lacks the competitive depth where podium times drive each other to elite levels.

value.explanation: $85 for first 200 riders gets you 72 miles through mountain gravel including private roads you can't ride otherwise. Free hot meal, cold beer, and downtown festival atmosphere with Main Street closed to traffic adds substantial value beyond the riding.

expenses.explanation: Camping at Oconee State Park or South Cove County Park keeps lodging cheap near the start. Downtown Walhalla offers "sweet container house with a view" and "Lofts in Downtown Walhalla," with budget hotels 10 minutes away in Seneca.

citations.label: RideWithGPS: Official SEG The Race to Valhalla long course
